track_notes: I parked at Mimosa Market and hiked up the stairs to the trailhead.  A statue of Jesus and a tree full of hanging rubber chickens marked the trailhead entrance.  This hike is all on trail but you do enter mine property for a while - I am told they allow this as long as you stay on the trail.  After leaving the mine property you go onto AZ State Trust land, so you should carry a permit (available online).
Down version of the hike.  I did take a steeper but slightly shorter route down at the top.

I parked at GPS 31.44646, -109.91354 across the street from the Mimosa Market, which is closed on Mondays, so parking was easy to find. The steepest parts of the hike were at the beginning (lots of stairs to climb to get to the trailhead) and about the last 300 ft of elevation gain to the summit. The rest of the hike was relatively easy, and the trail was easy to follow until you get around the north side of the mountain. You have to keep an eye out for the trail--otherwise you end up bushwhacking. On the north side, the trail often follows bare rock or drainage, and it is easy to lose the trail. The North-South summit is rocky with good views. There are no trees, but it is easy to erect a mast and either a 66-ft or 133-ft long antenna. I did not bring my gaiters but wished I had. My time to ascend was 2h-15m and time to descend was 1h-45m. There is a summit register which is located in a rock cairn. Have fun! K9PM Paul
